quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.text: When you have a new network, think of it as a new country, you want the high status people and high status mean they're interesting, people want to be where they are in some shape or form because they have money, they're smart, they're cool, they're good-looking, whatever it may be and you want to get them onto your network. And there's exactly an interesting corollary that they're often underserved by other existing platforms.

quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.text: Every single time, I think you need to go after a set of people who are high status who are also underserved. What is more interesting for me is all the homegrown folks. You need interesting people from elsewhere, but you also need homegrown talent.

quotes.speaker: Aarthi Ramamurthy
quotes.text: I've come to realize that that is just not true and this might be a controversial opinion, but you have to get out there and build your own brand. You have to figure out what you stand for, what your core values are, what you believe in, what you think you want to do, what your next career trajectory is going to look like. All of that is just up to you. It's not up to the company to figure it out for you, it's not up to anybody else, it's just up to you.

quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.text: Put yourself out there because the internet rewards people being out there. And what happens when you put yourself out there? It's a Bat-Signal. It's telling people that, 'Hey, I'm here, this is my body of work,' and you know what the internet does? It'll send amazing people to you.

quotes.speaker: Aarthi Ramamurthy
quotes.text: You're almost better off doing these small, niche, non-scalable things to go find these oddball set of people who are doing this, who are really interested in this one thing and kind of scale from there and grow from there. When you're starting to build a community, don't start to build this super scaled community. Start with few people who are passionate about a particular problem.

quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.text: I really don't like the word community because the word community, the word networking, the word platform is a little abstract and it can mean a lot of things. And I like to think of things like a dinner party or church or things that seem more tangible. So when I think of a community or starting one, I think first of all, it's a party. You need to tell people, as the host, which one it is.

quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.text: If you just remember one thing from this whole thing is just get started and do something every single day. With creating content, diet and exercise, you just write a piece of content every single day because what's going to happen is it builds muscle, it gets you familiar with the medium and you start understanding what works in that medium and what doesn't and you start building reps.

quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.text: The thing I've learned to do is you have to retreat to a place where you feel real mastery of. Then you start with the base of something that you feel super comfortable in and you build from that. And what you realize when you build from that is people really respect that and they react to that. You just need to come from a place where you are confident you've done the work.

quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.text: Nobody I know has ever become successful by trying to fix their weaknesses, it's just impossible. The only way you succeed is you might need to mitigate some of them, especially if they're really holding you back. But you have to lean into your strengths. It's the superpowers that's going to really pull you ahead, so let's focus on that.

quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.text: I learned two lessons from that. One is the market is bigger than all of you. You can work with the amazing team, you can work with the A plus team, A plus company, but if the market shifts, you can't overcome a bad market or a bad space. The second part is if you feel some product is bad and if you feel like this new thing, it's just better to use, you have to follow the instinct.

quotes.speaker: Sriram Krishnan
quotes.text: Real life and real product is all about these trade-offs and whenever I've seen people trot out JTBD, it's a tell that they actually haven't dealt with a trade-off, where you have to make one person's life slightly worse in one situation for some other interesting dynamic.

quotes.speaker: Aarthi Ramamurthy
quotes.text: Really think about it as if your product didn't exist and if you had to start over from scratch, would you build it the exact same way for these set of customers? Oftentimes people hyper-focused on competition and what other company is doing. That almost never matters. Other companies are probably looking at you and going, 'What are these guys doing?'

takeaways: Building a personal brand is not optional even at big companies - you must define what you stand for because no company will do it for you, and putting yourself out there acts as a Bat-Signal that attracts opportunities and serendipity.

Communities should be thought of as dinner parties, not platforms - start small with a passionate niche, set the tone as host, curate the right mix of people, and establish rituals that create intimacy and trust over time.
New social networks grow by attracting high-status people who are underserved by existing platforms, while also nurturing homegrown talent that becomes uniquely identified with the new platform.
Overcome imposter syndrome by retreating to your area of genuine mastery and building outward from there - nobody succeeds by fixing weaknesses, only by leaning into superpowers.

Systems thinking beats Jobs-to-be-Done for real product decisions because actual products require trade-offs between multiple agents - sometimes making one user's experience worse to improve another's is the right call.

contrarian_candidates.why: Boldly declares Jobs-to-be-Done is a tell that someone hasn't dealt with real trade-offs - directly attacks a widely-revered product framework
Calls building personal brand a necessity, not vanity - contradicts the conventional corporate wisdom of 'let your work speak for itself'
Claims nobody succeeds by fixing weaknesses - challenges the standard performance review culture of focusing on areas for improvement
